messages: d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:02): i have a stupid question
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:02): RELAXNG, DTD, schemas,... they all serve to declaratively specify a grammar for a particular language...
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:03): couldn't they be replaced with a procedural imperative language?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:03): since, correct me if i'm wrong, things like SVG, HTML5 and CSS can't be validated simply with a DTD.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:04): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: replaced for what purpose?

d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: so that something like the internals of SVG's d attribute could be well-specified by something other than paragraphs of text
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:05): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: if for validation, the answer is "yes"
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ohhh, i forgot about BNF
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i guess i'm looking for something more meaningful than BNF
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:06): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: what you are looking for is Python or Java
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:06): ECMA claims to be using ML for ECMAScript 4 or 5
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yes, i wonder if the html5lib could be it
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:06): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: html5lib is just a parser
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: but i guess i thought it would be fun as part of a formal spec
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:07): that's true
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:07): but perhaps a validator + test suite for the validator could be a formal effort by the WG
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:08): in Python, perhaps
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:12): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: are you aware that there already is a non-vaporware project?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: no, what's it called?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:13): http:/ b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9.iki.fi/validator/html5/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:13): documentation: http:/ b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9.iki.fi/thesis/
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:15): is it schema validation only or do you intend to check attribute syntax?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:16): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: it is not validation only and I already check attribute syntax (but incompletely at this point)
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:16): <path d="M35,20 L23,35 ...." transform="scale(30, 40) rotate(10, 20) ..." />
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:16): SVG is on my todo list after HTML5
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:18): fascinating, well this is a great effort
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:18): it's too bad it's in java though
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:18): for me, it'll be harder to contribute
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:19): but i suppose, given the broad range of tools used to validate W3C specs it may be the right choice for its intended use
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:19): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: of garbage collected languages that run on various Unix-like systems Java has the best XML library ecosystem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:20): Python was the runner-up that didn't get chosen
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:20): i wonder if a HTML5 only one in Python could be written
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:20): that was shorter and easier for spec contributors to edit
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:21): anyway, more vaporware talk,
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (19:21): thinks d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e should take some time to read b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9's thesis

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: you do realize that my implementation is based on a RELAX NG schema for the most part and RELAX NG Compact Syntax is easier to edit than Python?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:22): part of the point of choosing Java is that Java has a RELAX NG validator written by one of the editors of the RELAX NG spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:23): the other reason is that SAX is ubiquitous in the Java world, so all libraries fit together
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (19:29): whenever i see that i think of frankie goes to hollywood
9fdcde97c1cb33fe4e9f6aab1d84bc76 (19:30): and the 'ng!' bit just adds to the aural imagery ‚Ä¶
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:39): i think i will do some more research
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:39): i thought that RELAX NG was only opaque outside of attributes
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:39): but i wonder what it does with HTML tag soup
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:39): so i will go and read up more on RELAX NG
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (19:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: very cool stuff
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:41): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: RELAX NG validators can use libraries implemented in Turing-complete languages to check the inside of attributes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:41): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: again, the API situation is the best for Java
